hl.seg: why reduce exercise with the age?
new research

doc.seg: Exercise at any age is good for health.
It energizes your heart, reduces the cholesterol level, helps in keeping the weight low, helps in preventing diabetes and slows down the process of Alzheimer's or dementia.
Unfortunately the ability to exercise reduces in many people with the age.
Experts say that exercise keep our body and brain active however age can affect it.
According to the American Medical Association, several health related problems can arise by not doing exercise.
Dr. Patricia Palecca, of Mayo Clinic Minnesota, says that an increase in age is a major cause of inability to exercise and lack of bodily activity.
Dr. Patricia teaches medicine at Mayo Clinic.
She lead a study of how heart related diseases and the ability to exercise is related to old age.
The team of doctors used high frequency sound waves to measure the working of the heart.
The pumping of the blood by the heart - its contraction and relaxation - was studied.
The experts focused on the left part of the heart which is the main part for pumping blood.
They learned that as people grew older there was an increase in faults in the relaxation of the heart.
Dr. Patricia says that as age increases the faults in the relaxation of the heart begin to appear and this affects the ability to exercise.
Dr. Garwin Cain was also a part of this study.

He says that they were surprised to see that there is a definite effect of this and that this clearly proves how deep of a relationship there is between the decrease of exercise and the relaxation of the heart.
Sometimes blood pressure can cause faults in the working of the heart and can become a cause of heart disease.
If the doctor and the patient work together on the faults of the heart they can achieve the benefits of exercise, despite the increase in age.
A detailed report of this has been published in the magazine of the American Medical Association.
